fs.xml
Class PolyglotStringTable

java.lang.Object
  fs.xml.PolyglotStringTable
All Implemented Interfaces:
ResourceDependent, XMLConfigurable
Direct Known Subclasses:
PolyglotTableModel
public class PolyglotStringTable
extends java.lang.Object
implements ResourceDependent, XMLConfigurable

Implements a table of strings, each identified by unique String ID and potentially available in multiple languages. Each PolyglotStringTable is supposed to identify itself by a possibly unique ID and an optional description (i.e. of its purpose and content). It contains as well a table of 'Supported Languages', each with Identifier and description. As this table and the string table is maintained by the user, a priori it can only serve informational purposes. No actual guarantee can be given, that a certain string exists in a certain language. This class also contains a table mapping certain string id's to group id's. These group id's are for example used by the application POLYGLOT to arrange the strings in a clearer way. The group id's impose a hierarchical grouping similar to package hierarchy: A '.' in the group id indicates a subgrouping. Formatted strings with placeholder arguments are supported.
The input/output format is XML. The format is strict and described under "schema/PolyglotStringTable.xsd". Internally the tables will be saved in HashMaps, for performance reasons. Input/output operations are performed via the XMLConfigurable interface. The method configure() however, does not implement a simple loading mechanism, but adds content to the existing table.
For the class to be fully functional the schema and template files - as specified by the ResourceDependent interface - have to be present.

Author:
Simon Hampe

PolyglotStringTable

public PolyglotStringTable(java.lang.String id,
                           java.lang.String description)
Constructs a String table with empty language list and no string IDs. The table's id and description are set to the specified values (null will be interpreted as the empty string). Schema and template files are supposed to be in the standard subfolder of the current application folder

Will return the string associated with the specified ID and language, with placeholders replaced by appropriate arguments. If the string ID does not exist or the string does not exist for the given String and Language ID, null is returned.

Throws:
java.util.MissingFormatArgumentException - - if the arguments provided do not match the string's format (a surplus of arguments will be ignored).

getMissingStrings

public java.util.HashMap<java.lang.String,java.util.HashSet<java.lang.String>> getMissingStrings()
Returns a HashMap containing all tuples (StringID, List of LanguageIDs) for which the StringID exists in this table and the LanguageIDs are contained in the language list, but for which no strings exists (i.e. getString(StringID, LanguageID) == null for each element in the list of LanguageIDs).

isCompleteGroup

public boolean isCompleteGroup(java.lang.String groupID)
Returns true, if and only if for each string in this group and its subgroups, there exists a variant for each listed language. (Thus this also returns true for group id's not in this tree)

setLanguageDescription

public void setLanguageDescription(java.lang.String languageID,
                                   java.lang.String description)
Sets the description of the specified language. If the languageID is not contained in the language list of this table, this call is ignored.

putLanguage

public void putLanguage(java.lang.String languageID,
                        java.lang.String description)
Adds the languageID to the list of languages and sets its description to the specified value. If the ID is already contained in the list, its description will simply be set to the new value.

removeLanguage

public void removeLanguage(java.lang.String languageID)
Removes the specified languageID from the list of languages

addStringID

public void addStringID(java.lang.String stringID)
Adds the specified StringID to the list without inserting any variants. If the StringID already exists, this call is ignored

removeID

public void removeID(java.lang.String stringID)
Removes an ID and all associated variants from this table. If the ID does not exist, this call is ignored. Possible references in the group table are removed as well.

putString

public void putString(java.lang.String stringID,
                      java.lang.String languageID,
                      java.lang.String value)
Sets the string value for the specified stringID and languageID to the specified value. If the stringID does not exist, it is inserted. If the languageID does not exist, however, it will not automatically be inserted into the language list, though an entry in this language will exist under the stringID passed as first argument. If a variant already exists for these IDs it will be overwritten. Group references will be preserved. If value == null, no variant will be created or an existing variant will be removed. If stringID or languageID == null, this call is ignored

putString

public void putString(java.lang.String stringID,
                      java.lang.String languageID,
                      java.lang.String groupID,
                      java.lang.String value)
Sets the string value for the specified stringID and languageID to the specified value. If the stringID does not exist, it is inserted. If the languageID does not exist, however, it will not automatically be inserted into the language list, though an entry in this language will exist under the stringID passed as first argument. If a variant already exists for these IDs it will be overwritten. Whatever the case, the group attribute of this string will be set to groupID afterwards.

renameString

public void renameString(java.lang.String oldID,
                         java.lang.String newID)
This renames a string id, i.e.: All variants that were originally obtained under the old id, are now obtained under the new one and the old id is removed from its group and the new id added. If the old id doesn't exist or one of the ids is null, this call is ignored. If the new id already exists, it is overwritten.

setTableID

public void setTableID(java.lang.String tableID)
Sets the String that identified the table in the context of XMLConfigurables. If the new ID equals null, this call is ignored

See Also:
XMLConfigurable

setTableDescription

public void setTableDescription(java.lang.String desc)
Sets the description of this table to the specified value (null values are interpreted as empty strings)

setGroupID

public void setGroupID(java.lang.String stringID,
                       java.lang.String groupID)
If stringID exists in this table, its group is set to the specified group id. Otherwise, this call is ignored.

assignReference

Assigns the ResourceReference that is used to locate templates and schema files. If r == null, the default reference is used

Specified by:
assignReference in interface ResourceDependent

getExpectedResourceStructure

public org.dom4j.Document getExpectedResourceStructure()
This returns the same for all PolyglotStringTables: A subdirectory "schema" containing PolyglotStringTable.xsd, a subdirectory "templates" containing "tmpl_PolyglotStringTable.xml" and a subdirectory "language", containing "fsfwStringTable.xml"

Specified by:
getExpectedResourceStructure in interface ResourceDependent

configure

public void configure(org.dom4j.Node n)
               throws XMLWriteConfigurationException
Will try to read the node n as if being the root node of an XML document. satisfying the PolyglotStringTable schema definition. The table's content will be changed in the following way:
- Table id and description will not be changed
- All language ID's in n that are not yet in the list of languages of this table, will be added with their description
- For all language ID's in n that are already present in the list of languages the description will be overwritten by the description in n
- All String ID's that are not yet in the list of stringIDs of this table, will be added with all variants
- For all String ID's already present in this table, already existing variants are overwritten by those in n and additional variants are added.
- All polyglotstrings in n with an existing group attribute will be associated to this group, no matter if they already existed before.

Thus this method can be used to 'update' a table, i.e. replace erroneous strings or add support for another language.

Specified by:
configure in interface XMLConfigurable
Throws:
XMLWriteConfigurationException - , if the configuration passed on ist not a valid configuration or null

getConfiguration

public org.dom4j.Element getConfiguration()
                                   throws XMLReadConfigurationException
Returns the root element of a tree that forms an XML document conforming to the PolyglotStringTable schema definition that contains all data of this string table

Specified by:
getConfiguration in interface XMLConfigurable
Returns:
The current configuration
Throws:
XMLReadConfigurationException - if isConfigured() == false or the configuration can not be returned for some other reason

the (supposedly) unique ID

Returns always true

clone

public PolyglotStringTable clone()
Returns a deep copy of the string table. Since the resource reference cannot be deep-cloned, it is simply copied.

Overrides:
clone in class java.lang.Object

cutGroupPath

public static java.lang.String cutGroupPath(java.lang.String id)
This extracts the portion of the string after the last occurrence of a point (including this point) If there is no point, the complete group name is displayed

isSubgroupOf

public static boolean isSubgroupOf(java.lang.String group,
                                   java.lang.String subgroup,
                                   boolean strict)
Returns:
true, if and only if:
- group == null or
- group, subgroup != null and strict == true and subgroup.startswith(group + ".") or
- group, subgroup != null and strict == false and subgroup.startswith(group + ".") || subgroup.equals(group)

extractGroup

public static java.lang.String extractGroup(java.lang.String prefix,
                                            java.lang.String groupID)
Extracts a group name from groupID in the following way:
- If groupID == null, this returns null
- If prefix == null this returns the highest order group name in group ID
- If groupID doesn't start with prefix, this returns null
- If groupID.equals(prefix), this returns null
- Otherwise this returns prefix + "." + the highest order group name in group ID after prefix

extractHighestGroup

public static java.lang.String extractHighestGroup(java.lang.String groupID)
Returns:
- null, if groupID == null
- The prefix of groupID up to and not including the first occurence of "."

loadFsfwTable

public static PolyglotStringTable loadFsfwTable(ResourceReference r)
                                         throws XMLWriteConfigurationException
Returns a clone of the table created by (fsframework)/language/fsfwStringTable.xml, which contains strings used by several framework classes. It wil be loaded using the resource reference specified. If r is null, the default reference will be used. This will load a new copy from the XML file each time the mehtod is called. If you want to load a cached version, call getFsfwTable(), which returns the last version loaded.

Throws:
XMLWriteConfigurationException - - if any error occured during document loading

getFsfwTable

public static PolyglotStringTable getFsfwTable()
Will return the last version of the fsframework table loaded (i.e. the last version generated by loadFsfwTable(ResourceReference r)). If there is none (i.e. the internal copy is null), the method will try to load it using the default resource reference. If this is not succesful, null is returned.

getGlobalLanguageID

public static java.lang.String getGlobalLanguageID()
Returns:
The global language ID for fsframework. It can be set via setGlobalLanguageID. This has nothing to do with the defaut language ID of the fs.xml.PolyglotStringLoader, which is "en" and cannot be changed. However, some framework classes require a language to be specified upon instance creation. Usually, if null is specified here, the global language id is used

setGlobalLanguageID

public static void setGlobalLanguageID(java.lang.String globalLanguageID)
This sets the global default language ID for fsframework. All class using this ID, which are instantiated afterwards, will use it. However, instances that were created before will not be notified of this change and might thus show incoherent behavior (certain buttons displayed in dutch while the tooltips are still in greek, etc...) As a rule of thumb, this method should be called, before any language-dependent classes are instantiated.
